Someone encrypted a secret using RSA, but chose both primes as Blum integers. Can you exploit this flaw to recover the message from 990633330686194633133842631064668188869231169421774020537518733727709542303557321971290787695004174286691528673925113024994491371338208774896977181873399?

The flag format is flag{...}
n=3943676467581733946923230826061176372518469416727627011950210509772468130161241947336151089994066497744309743231832647611378498627151261083359880489051361, e=2717261382202459431672069789004104497110956204445694218378076164780543308487368766590422228779726050449600485517955722993334090149659367293382718917613419
The lower 104 bits of p are: 23911357651541675049421673114425314495


---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{rsc57xrr}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 990633330686194633133842631064668188869231169421774020537518733727709542303557321971290787695004174286691528673925113024994491371338208774896977181873399
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=3943676467581733946923230826061176372518469416727627011950210509772468130161241947336151089994066497744309743231832647611378498627151261083359880489051361, e=2717261382202459431672069789004104497110956204445694218378076164780543308487368766590422228779726050449600485517955722993334090149659367293382718917613419
The lower 104 bits of p are: 23911357651541675049421673114425314495

extra_info: p=59111379120286408661277649512492176481923598271130734335073341567014777081023, q=66716028728693716500947109920637064886716238742940693471993239067345160525407, Ï†(n)=3943676467581733946923230826061176372518469416727627011950210509772468130161116119928302109868904272984876613990464007774364427199344194502725520551444932
